nodes.text: Partial modelling using Boolean networks (BNs) and combining partial models can serve as an inductive discovery procedure to develop economic theory and improve prediction of economic phenomena

Proposed method: combine Boolean network partial models into larger models, simplify partial models (e.g. exclude node values that produce multiple steady states), exclude feedback loops, and possibly convert BNs to continuous dynamical systems (ODEs)
In systems biology the term 'predict' often refers to reproducing known or non-surprising results or to calibration, not to blind-tested forecasting of novel events
BNs are remarkably flexible, which allows fitting known data but risks poor non-trivial prediction and overfitting
Simplifying or pruning features (e.g. removing feedback loops, multiple steady states) when combining partial models can remove crucial dynamics and distort realism
Evidence from yeast gene regulation: experimentally verified prediction concerned stochastic effects invisible to ODE models regardless of added equations or parameters (Ramsey et al. 2006)

Evidence from cancer drug modelling: predictive, blind-tested models used by industry require combined ODE/agent-based approaches and limit parameters to measurables, since BNs or ODEs alone cannot capture required dynamical cell population effects
Evidence that simpler models can outperform large complex models: a small model outperformed large-scale biophysical cardiac models at predicting cardiac toxicity of drug compounds (Mistry 2018)

Claim: The core problem in modelling complex living systems and economies is model structure and complexity, not merely scope or size, so adding nodes or joining patches does not necessarily solve modelling deficiencies

Evidence/claim: Complex systems exhibit 'sloppy' parameter sensitivities and hidden opposing feedback loops that are hard to identify from data, leading to large uncertainty and potential instability when model parameters change

Conclusion: Joining and extending partial models using BNs while pruning destabilising features is unlikely to address the main problems of economic models (missing structure, hidden feedbacks, sloppy parameters), so this strategy may not produce better predictive or realistic economic models

Proposed alternative: adopt a dashboard approach that uses a range of mostly separate model types (ODEs, stochastic models, agent-based models, machine learning, BNs) as complementary partial models, keeping model size limited to avoid dimensionality and parameter identification problems

Claim: Incentives and funding sources shape modelling assumptions and the questions asked, so before combining models one should investigate influences such as the source of funds and sectoral interests

Conclusion: Economics can learn from systems biology's plural modeling toolbox but should prefer complementary separate models and consideration of incentives over semi-automatic patching and expansion of BNs into comprehensive models
